messages.text:
Hey guys,

I am happy to announce that I have just prepared the skeleton of the Julia package JMcDM which basically implements Saw, ARAS, NDS, Topsis, Electre, Dematel, Moora, Vikor, and AHP (Analytical hierarchy process) as multiple criteria decision making tools. The package also implements single criterion tools such as maximin, minimax, MLE, Savage, Laplace, and Expected Regret. A game solver is also implemented for zero sum games using JuMP and Cbc back-ends.

There is a list of unimplemented methods including PROMETHEE, MACBETH, COMET, etc. in the project repository.

I am planning to have a comprehensive tool for this subject and prepare the high quality documentation for developers. I am also planning to write a journal article, possibly for SoftwareX, of course with all of the developers and contributors.

So, this is an announcement and *an open invitation* for both package development and submitting a journal paper after it gets a mature level.

The repository is <https://github.com/jbytecode/JMcDM>

Thank you in advance!

I am happy to announce that I have just prepared the skeleton of the Julia package JMcDM which basically implements Saw, ARAS, NDS, Topsis, Electre, Dematel, Moora, Vikor, and AHP (Analytical hierarchy process) as multiple criteria decision making tools. The package also implements single criterion tools such as maximin, minimax, MLE, Savage, Laplace, and Expected Regret. A game solver is also implemented for zero sum games using JuMP and Cbc back-ends.

There is a list of unimplemented methods including PROMETHEE, MACBETH, COMET, etc. in the project repository.

I am planning to have a comprehensive tool for this subject and prepare the high quality documentation for developers. I am also planning to write a journal article, possibly for SoftwareX, of course with all of the developers and contributors.

So, this is an announcement and

messages.text:
Hi all, I am having trouble generating names for an empty DataFrame.  I need to generate them as follows:
```df = DataFrame()
names!(df, [Symbol(i) for i in 1.5:0.5:5])```
But this throws an error because the data frame doesn’t expect that many column names.  Does anyone know how to do this?  I don’t have to want to write
```df = DataFrame(1.5 = Float64[], 2.0 = Float64[], 2.5 = Float64[]) # etc.```
because that will take a long time…

elements.text: Hi all, I am having trouble generating names for an empty DataFrame.  I need to generate them as follows:

df = DataFrame()
names!(df, [Symbol(i) for i in 1.5:0.5:5])
But this throws an error because the data frame doesn’t expect that many column names.  Does anyone know how to do this?  I don’t have to want to write
df = DataFrame(1.5 = Float64[], 2.0 = Float64[], 2.5 = Float64[]) # etc.
because that will take a long time…

messages.text:
hello all, I believe there is a bug in 1.6 where `bytesavailable` always returns 0.  Has anyone run into this?  several of us started discussing it on zulip
```julia> open(io -> write(io, "what up"), "testfile.txt", "w+")
7

julia> f = open("testfile.txt")
IOStream(<file testfile.txt>)

julia> bytesavailable(f)
0

julia> readavailable(f)
7-element Vector{UInt8}:
 0x77
 0x68
 0x61
 0x74
 0x20
 0x75
 0x70```

messages.text:
Can I convert an Array with `Any` elements with something thats more concrete? I have code that looks like
```function run_sims(params) 
    nsims = 5
    sols = []
    for sim in 1:nsims       
        println("sim: $sim")   
        sample_params(params)
        push!(sols, _simulate(params))
    end
    return sols
end```
but the `typeof(sols)` says it's an array with element `Any`. The return object from `_simulate` is actually is known. It's an ODE Solution, but the type is quite long.
```julia> typeof(sol)
ODESolution{Float64,2,Array{Array{Float64,1},1},Nothing,Nothing,Array{Float64,1},Array{Array{Array{Float64,1},1},1},ODEProblem{Array{Float64,1},Tuple{Float64,Float64},true,ModelParameters,ODEFunction{true,typeof(aModel!),UniformScaling{Bool},Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing},Base.Iterators.Pairs{Union{},Union{},Tuple{},NamedTuple{(),Tuple{}}},DiffEqBase.StandardODEProblem},Rodas4{0,false,DefaultLinSolve,DataType},OrdinaryDiffEq.InterpolationData{ODEFunction{true,typeof(aModel!),UniformScaling{Bool},Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing},Array{Array{Float64,1},1},Array{Float64,1},Array{Array{Array{Float64,1},1},1},OrdinaryDiffEq.Rodas4Cache{Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,2},Array{Float64,2},OrdinaryDiffEq.RodasTableau{Float64,Float64},DiffEqBase.TimeGradientWrapper{ODEFunction{true,typeof(aModel!),UniformScaling{Bool},Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing},Array{Float64,1},ModelParameters},DiffEqBase.UJacobianWrapper{ODEFunction{true,typeof(aModel!),UniformScaling{Bool},Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing,Nothing},Float64,ModelParameters},DefaultLinSolve,FiniteDiff.JacobianCache{Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,1},UnitRange{Int64},Nothing,Val{:forward}(),Float64},FiniteDiff.GradientCache{Nothing,Array{Float64,1},Array{Float64,1},Float64,Val{:forward}(),Float64,Val{true}()}}},DiffEqBase.DEStats}```

function run_sims(params) 
    nsims = 5
    temp_sim = _simulate(params)
    sols = Array{typeof(temp_sim), 1}()
    for sim in 1:nsims       
        println("sim: $sim")   
        sample_params(params)
        push!(sols, _simulate(params))
    end
    return sols```
where I've run a single simulation before just to get the type

messages.text: There is also `return_type`
like `sols = Vector{Core.Compiler.return_type(_simulate, Tuple{typeof(params)})}()`

You can just do `identity.(xs)`
```julia> xs = Any[1, 2.0, 3]
3-element Vector{Any}:
 1
 2.0
 3

julia> identity.(xs)
3-element Vector{Real}:
 1
 2.0
 3 ```

messages.text:
MIT Press has just signed off on an agreement that allows us to post a PDF of our 2019 book "Algorithms for Optimization" online: <https://algorithmsbook.com/optimization>
(Not to be confused with our "Algorithms for Decision Making" book that we released last month at <https://algorithmsbook.com>. The print version will be available from MIT Press in 2022.)
All algorithms are implemented in Julia.

All algorithms are implemented in Julia.

messages.text:
Probably a basic question but I am from a stat (non CS) background trying to wrap my head around KD-Trees and I have the following:
``` 
 struct KdNode
     point::Tuple
     left::KdNode
     right::KdNode
     level::Int64
     KdNode() = (x=new();x.left=x;x.right=x)
 end

 KdNode((3,5,7),nothing,nothing,2) #error no method matching..
     ```
How do I initialize the first instance here in Julia? I tried stuff from <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/constructors/#Incomplete-Initialization> but I don't think I am doing it right.

but I don't think I am doing it right.

messages.text: I have an issue with using the up-arrow key to go back in the history in the REPL, that arrises after I’ve shelled out to a powershell script. If I do `run(`pwsh -NoProfile hellowold.ps1`)` , where `helloworld.ps1` simply is `Write-Host "Hello world"` , then subsequent scrolling through history fails. `run(`echo 123`)`  does not provoke this behavior. Should this be reported somewhere? I’m on OSX and Julia 1.6 rc1.

messages.text:

*julia>* m = JuMP.read_from_file(“rootnodemodel.mps”)

messages.text: Is there a Julia Stack Exchange? if not? why not? I use LaTeX a lot, and I love that within a quick search, I can find every answer to every question about LaTeX on the stack exchange. While this is a good place to congregate, I thought that a common place for Q's and A's to be addressed would be nice. Plus slack comments older than 10,000 recent posts requires a premium account, making it impossible for me to search if someone had the same question one month ago.

messages.text: From time to time I experience a funny issue on windows. I start to update a package with `]up PkgName` , then for some reason or another I kill the process with `ctrl+c` , the process gets killed but some folders in my `registries/General` get also deleted. The first time I experienced this it was the letters from `A`  to `C` , not it was from  `T` onwards. is this a known issue, has anyone else experienced it?

elements.text: From time to time I experience a funny issue on windows. I start to update a package with

messages.text: Yeah, you are interrupting a copying process so only a partial copy is performed. But it will be fixed in 1.6

elements.text: Yeah, you are interrupting a copying process so only a partial copy is performed. But it will be fixed in 1.6

messages.text: Hi folks, I have a question about Julia code executing sequence. I have a function “func” that consists of 3 functions. func1 creates a file; func2 modifies the file; func3 processes the file. If I call 3 functions sequentially in Julia REPL, it works fine. However, when I call “func” in Julia, it pops an error, which looks like func3 was called before func2 was finished.  How comes this happen? Any comments are appreciated.

elements.text: Hi folks, I have a question about Julia code executing sequence. I have a function “func” that consists of 3 functions. func1 creates a file; func2 modifies the file; func3 processes the file. If I call 3 functions sequentially in Julia REPL, it works fine. However, when I call “func” in Julia, it pops an error, which looks like func3 was called before func2 was finished.  How comes this happen? Any comments are appreciated.

A question about using Dict to organize a JSON file content. The JSON file I need at the end of the program looks like the following:
```{"file_name" : "2017-01-01.1.final.mps",
"ic8742": {
"x1": 345,
"x2": 433,
"x3": 123,
"rhs": 0}
}```
My data are mostly in dictionaries. I’m trying to use dict to get a JSON-like data structure and then save it as a JSON file. Here is my code, for example,
```ib_json_dict = Dict("file name" => file_name) 
dict = Dict(name(key)=> val for (key,val) in c.func.terms)
dict["rhs"] = c.func.constant
cut_name = name(conRef)
ib_json_dict[cut_name] = dict
write(ib_cut_file, ib_json_dict);  ```
But the following code does not work
```ib_json_dict[cut_name] = dict```
saying the following error
```ERROR: MethodError: Cannot `convert` an object of type Dict{String,Float64} to an object of type String```
I know this is wrong, but I don’t know how to fix it. Any inputs are appreciated!

elements.text: A question about using Dict to organize a JSON file content. The JSON file I need at the end of the program looks like the following:

ib_json_dict = Dict("file name" => file_name) 
dict = Dict(name(key)=> val for (key,val) in c.func.terms)
dict["rhs"] = c.func.constant
cut_name = name(conRef)
ib_json_dict[cut_name] = dict
write(ib_cut_file, ib_json_dict);
But the following code does not work

I know this is wrong, but I don’t know how to fix it. Any inputs are appreciated!

messages.text: here is the problem

```function find(word, letter)
    index = firstindex(word)
    while index <= sizeof(word)
        if word[index] == letter
            return index
        end
        index = nextind(word, index)
    end
    -1
end```

elements.text:
function find(word, letter)
    index = firstindex(word)
    while index <= sizeof(word)
        if word[index] == letter
            return index
        end
        index = nextind(word, index)
    end
    -1
end

messages.text: I don’t understand why Julia doesn’t support binding methods to structs at all. For example, all kinds of functions are just floating around in the module namespace of [Agents.jl](*<https://juliadynamics.github.io/Agents.jl/stable/api/#Agent/model-retrieval>)* with no anchor point. But some methods clearly belong to a certain struct: for example, `add_agent!` belongs to a model and `walk!` belongs to an agent. Agent-based modeling’s name already lends support to object-oriented programming, it’s really unfortunate that Julia insists on polluting the module’s namespace with myriad functions operating on different structs (many of them operate exclusively on a struct and there is no need for multiple dispatch).

elements.text: I don’t understand why Julia doesn’t support binding methods to structs at all. For example, all kinds of functions are just floating around in the module namespace of [Agents.jl](

with no anchor point. But some methods clearly belong to a certain struct: for example, `add_agent!` belongs to a model and `walk!` belongs to an agent. Agent-based modeling’s name already lends support to object-oriented programming, it’s really unfortunate that Julia insists on polluting the module’s namespace with myriad functions operating on different structs (many of them operate exclusively on a struct and there is no need for multiple dispatch).

messages.text:
> In python, some functions live in the module namespace, some are methods bound to objects. There seems to be no such confusion.
Unlike Python, Julia tends to have a design philosophy, you can call the Zen of Julia, that there should be one, and preferably only one, way to do things. It simplifies the design and ensures uniformity and predictability.

root.text: I don’t understand why Julia doesn’t support binding methods to structs at all. For example, all kinds of functions are just floating around in the module namespace of [Agents.jl](*<https://juliadynamics.github.io/Agents.jl/stable/api/#Agent/model-retrieval>)* with no anchor point. But some methods clearly belong to a certain struct: for example, `add_agent!` belongs to a model and `walk!` belongs to an agent. Agent-based modeling’s name already lends support to object-oriented programming, it’s really unfortunate that Julia insists on polluting the module’s namespace with myriad functions operating on different structs (many of them operate exclusively on a struct and there is no need for multiple dispatch).

elements.text: I don’t understand why Julia doesn’t support binding methods to structs at all. For example, all kinds of functions are just floating around in the module namespace of [Agents.jl](

with no anchor point. But some methods clearly belong to a certain struct: for example, `add_agent!` belongs to a model and `walk!` belongs to an agent. Agent-based modeling’s name already lends support to object-oriented programming, it’s really unfortunate that Julia insists on polluting the module’s namespace with myriad functions operating on different structs (many of them operate exclusively on a struct and there is no need for multiple dispatch).
In python, some functions live in the module namespace, some are methods bound to objects. There seems to be no such confusion.

Unlike Python, Julia tends to have a design philosophy, you can call the Zen of Julia, that there should be one, and preferably only one, way to do things. It simplifies the design and ensures uniformity and predictability.

messages.text:
Does anyone know why an `include` command can take almost a minute to load?
```julia> @time include("model.jl")
 52.720173 seconds (104.91 M allocations: 5.629 GiB, 4.09% gc time)
ngm2 (generic function with 1 method)```
All I have there are a few structs and functions, no global variables or consts at all.

The situation is even worse when I do `addprocs()` and have about 300 worker processes. Takes 10 to 15 minutes to run the `include` command (because I am guessing it's automatically running the code on all processes sequentially?)

I am on v1.4. Does 1.5 or 1.6rc make this better?

messages.text:
What I have:
